V hen General Maude first took over the Command of this (. lorce) the political machinery id the Basra vilayet was firmly established and working smoothly, while on the Tigris front no political issues of any importance were arising so that up to the time of our arrivaj here, and indeed up to the time of Secretary of State’s telegram of 20th March regarding future administration of this country, I have had little opportunity to gauge his attitude in regard to political questions. Since then, however, political problems have been continually arising, and I feel it my duty to acquaint His Majesty s (lovernment with the position which has become unsatisfactory from a political point of view. (General Maude’s military successes have established his reputation as a soldier beyond all criticism, but he is purely a soldier and without any previous experience of the East or of Orientals, and I find him, as is only natural, unsympathetic and somewhat intolerant in regard to political problems and unable to appreciate important bearing of apparently simple problems of daily occurrence on larger political and even military interests. With the limited power which I at present possess as his Chief Political Officer, which gives me no right to report to Government, and having regard to his pronounced divergence of outlook, I find myself unable to make good the undertaking which I have given to Government to allow nothing to be done calculated to prejudice their declared policy, and I realise that if that policy is to be safeguarded, I must be placed in a stronger position vis-d-vis the Army Commander, and at any rate to be given right to send a regular report weekly or fortnightly to higher authority to keep them au fait with current questions and at large. As His Majesty’s Government are aware, I have no ulterior ambitions here, and am quite ready to resign if that course is convenient to them, but if it is desired that 1 should remain, my hands must be strengthened. If this could best be done by making me High Commissioner nominally, I woidd no longer oppose it provided it is under stood that it does not connote any more extensive introduction of Arab administration than was recently agreed upon, but simply placing His Majesty’s Government in a better position to keep themselves closely informed of political developments in the new territory. If the [? portent (sic)] of my being made High Commissioner could be limited as above, I do not think Army Commander would raise any-objection. There had better be no increase in pay as it would bring mine to more than his. I should, of course, give him copies of my reports, but mere fact of my having right to [? differential treatment] would serve both as a safeguard and as a safety valve. It could be done in connection with arrival of General Clayton without giving rise to controversy. Failing some such action on above lines, I think it would be better if I were relieved. SIR P. Important Sheikhs are here or are expected with whom negotiations are in progress, and difficult political issues frequently arise, which it is not fair to leave a junior officer (to) deal with. Position is simply this : In case of present Army Commander it is doubtful whether the status ami functions of the Chief Civil Official are sufficient to ensure that the civil and political interests of the State in these territories, present and future, are sufficiently safeguarded. mods.abstract: This collection of telegrams relate to the professional differences between Lieutenant-Colonel Sir Percy Zachariah Cox, Chief Political Officer, and General Sir Frederick Stanley Maude. In the telegrams, Cox requests to be given more influence in his role or to be released from his duties. The bulk of the telegrams come from Cox himself, with shorter telegrams between the Viceroy and Secretary of State for India discussing how the situation should be dealt with.
